verses.text: Therefore on account of such an arrangement on the part of destructive Discord of this divided world, Empedocles admonishes his disciples to abstain from all sorts of animal food.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:47
verses.text: For he asserts that the bodies of animals are such as feed on the habitations of punished souls.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:48
verses.text: And he teaches those who are hearers of such doctrines (as his), to refrain from intercourse with women.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:49
verses.text: (And he issues this precept) in order that (his disciples) may not co-operate with and assist those works which Discord fabricates, always dissolving and forcibly severing the work of Friendship.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:50
verses.text: Empedocles asserts that this is the greatest law of the management of the universe, expressing himself somehow thus:—  "There's something swayed by Fate, the ancient,  Endless law of gods, and sealed by potent oaths".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:51
verses.text: He thus calls Fate the alteration from unity into plurality, according to Discord, and from plurality into unity, according to Friendship.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:52
verses.text: And, as I stated, (Empedocles asserts) that there are four perishable gods, (viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:53
verses.text: ,) fire, water, earth, (and) air.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:54
verses.text: (He maintains,) however, that there are two (gods) which are immortal, unbegotten, (and) continually hostile one to the other, (namely) Discord and Friendship.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:55
verses.text: And (he asserts) that Discord always is guilty of injustice and covetousness, and forcible abduction of the things of Friendship, and of appropriation of them to itself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:56
verses.text: (He alleges,) however, that Friendship, inasmuch as it is always and invariably a certain good (power), and intent on union, recalls and brings towards (itself), and reduces to unity, the parts of the universe that have been forcibly severed, and tormented, and punished in the creation by the Demiurge.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:57
verses.text: Some such system of philosophy as the foregoing is advanced for us by Empedocles concerning the generation of the world, and its destruction, and its constitution, as one consisting of what is good and bad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:58
verses.text: And he says that there is likewise a certain third power which is cognised by intellect, and that this can be understood from these, (viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:59
verses.text: , Discord and Friendship,) expressing himself somehow thus:—  "For if, 'neath hearts of oak, these truths you fix,  And view them kindly in meditations pure,  Each one of these, in lapse of time, will haunt you,  And many others, sprung of these, descend.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 17:60
verses.text: For into every habit these will grow, as Nature prompts;  But if for other things you sigh, which, countless, linger  Undisguised 'mid men, and blunt the edge of care,  As years roll on they'll leave you fleetly,  Since they yearn to reach their own beloved race;  For know that all possess perception and a share of mind".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:1
verses.text: Source of Marcionism; Empedocles Reasserted as the Suggester of the Heresy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:2
verses.text: When, therefore, Marcion or some one of his hounds barks against the Demiurge, and adduces reasons from a comparison of what is good and bad, we ought to say to them, that neither Paul the apostle nor Mark, he of the maimed finger, announced such (tenets).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:3
verses.text: For none of these (doctrines) has been written in the Gospel according to Mark.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:4
verses.text: But (the real author of the system) is Empedocles, son of Meto, a native of Agrigentum.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:5
verses.text: And (Marcion) despoiled this (philosopher), and imagined that up to the present would pass undetected his transference, under the same expressions, of the arrangement of his entire heresy from Sicily into the evangelical narratives.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:6
verses.text: For bear with me, O Marcion: as you have instituted a comparison of what is good and evil, I also to-day will institute a comparison following up your own tenets, as you suppose them to be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:7
verses.text: You affirm that the Demiurge of the world is evil—why not hide your countenance in shame, (as thus) teaching to the Church the doctrines of Empedocles? You say that there is a good Deity who destroys the works of the Demiurge: then do not you plainly preach to your pupils, as the good Deity, the Friendship of Empedocles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:8
verses.text: You forbid marriage, the procreation of children, (and) the abstaining from meats which God has created for participation by the faithful, and those that know the truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:9
verses.text: (Thinkest thou, then,) that thou canst escape detection, (while thus) enjoining the purificatory rites of Empedocles? For in point of fact you follow in every respect this (philosopher of paganism), while you instruct your own disciples to refuse meats, in order not to eat any body (that might be) a remnant of a soul which has been punished by the Demiurge.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:10
verses.text: You dissolve marriages that have been cemented by the Deity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:11
verses.text: And here again you conform to the tenets of Empedocles, in order that for you the work of Friendship may be perpetuated as one (and) indivisible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 18:12
verses.text: For, according to Empedocles, matrimony separates unity, and makes (out of it) plurality, as we have proved.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:1
verses.text: The Heresy of Prepon; Follows Empedocles; Marcion Rejects the Generation of the Saviour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:2
verses.text: The principal heresy of Marcion, and (the one of his) which is most free from admixture (with other heresies), is that which has its system formed out of the theory concerning the good and bad (God).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:3
verses.text: Now this, it has been manifested by us, belongs to Empedocles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:4
verses.text: But since at present, in our times, a certain follower of Marcion, (namely) Prepon, an Assyrian, has endeavoured to introduce something more novel, and has given an account of his heresy in a work inscribed to Bardesanes, an Armenian, neither of this will I be silent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:5
verses.text: In alleging that what is just constitutes a third principle, and that it is placed intermediate between what is good and bad, Prepon of course is not able to avoid (the imputation of inculcating) the opinion of Empedocles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:6
verses.text: For Empedocles asserts that the world is managed by wicked Discord, and that the other (world) which (is managed) by Friendship, is cognisable by intellect.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:7
verses.text: And (he asserts) that these are the two different principles of good and evil, and that intermediate between these diverse principles is impartial reason, in accordance with which are united the things that have been separated by Discord, (and which,) in accordance with the influence of Friendship, are accommodated to unity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:8
verses.text: The impartial reason itself, that which is an auxiliary to Friendship, Empedocles denominates "Musa".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:9
verses.text: And he himself likewise entreats her to assist him, and expresses himself somehow thus:—  "For if on fleeting mortals, deathless Muse,  Thy care it be that thoughts our mind engross,  Calliope, again befriend my present prayer,  As I disclose a pure account of happy gods".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:10
verses.text: Marcion, adopting these sentiments, rejected altogether the generation of our Saviour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:11
verses.text: He considered it to be absurd that under the (category of a) creature fashioned by destructive Discord should have been the Logos that was an auxiliary to Friendship—that is, the Good Deity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:12
verses.text: (His doctrine,) however, was that, independent of birth, (the Logos) Himself descended from above in the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, and that, as being intermediate between the good and bad Deity, He proceeded to give instruction in the synagogues.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:13
verses.text: For if He is a Mediator, He has been, he says, liberated from the entire nature of the Evil Deity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:14
verses.text: Now, as he affirms, the Demiurge is evil, and his works.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:15
verses.text: For this reason, he affirms, Jesus came down unbegotten, in order that He might be liberated from all (admixture of) evil.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:16
verses.text: And He has, he says, been liberated from the nature of the Good One likewise, in order that He may be a Mediator, as Paul states, and as Himself acknowledges: "Why call ye me good? there is one good".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:17
verses.text: These, then, are the opinions of Marcion, by means of which he made many his dupes, employing the conclusions of Empedocles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:18
verses.text: And he transferred the philosophy invented by that (ancient speculator) into his own system of thought, and (out of Empedocles) constructed his (own) impious heresy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:19
verses.text: But I consider that this has been sufficiently refuted by us, and that I have not omitted any opinion of those who purloin their opinions from the Greeks, and act despitefully towards the disciples of Christ, as if they had become teachers to them of these (tenets).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 19:20
verses.text: But since it seems that we have sufficiently explained the doctrines of this (heretic), let us see what Carpocrates says.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:1
verses.text: The Heresy of Carpocrates; Wicked Doctrines Concerning Jesus Christ; Practise Magical Arts; Adopt a Metempsychosis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:2
verses.text: Carpocrates affirms that the world and the things in it were made by angels, far inferior to the unbegotten Father; and that Jesus was generated of Joseph, and that, having been born similar to (other) men, He was more just than the rest (of the human race).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:3
verses.text: And (Carpocrates asserts) that the soul (of Jesus), inasmuch as it was made vigorous and undefiled, remembered the things seen by it in its converse with the unbegotten God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:4
verses.text: And (Carpocrates maintains) that on this account there was sent down upon (Jesus) by that (God) a power, in order that through it He might be enabled to escape the world-making (angels).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:5
verses.text: And (he says) that this power, having passed through all, and having obtained liberty in all, again ascended to God (Himself).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:6
verses.text: And (he alleges) that in the same condition with (the soul of Jesus are all the souls) that embrace similar objects of desire with the (power just alluded to).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:7
verses.text: And they assert that the soul of Jesus, (though,) according to law, it was disciplined in Jewish customs, (in reality) despised them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:8
verses.text: And (he says) that on this account (Jesus) received powers whereby He rendered null and void the passions incidental to men for their punishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:9
verses.text: And (he argues), therefore, that the (soul), which, similarly with that soul of Christ, is able to despise the world-making Archons, receives in like manner power for the performance of similar acts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:10
verses.text: Wherefore, also, (according to Carpocrates, there are persons who) have attained unto such a degree of pride as to affirm some of themselves to be equal to Jesus Himself, whereas others among them to be even still more powerful.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:11
verses.text: But (they also contend) that some enjoy an excellence above the disciples of that (Redeemer), for instance Peter and Paul, and the rest of the Apostles, and that these are in no respect inferior to Jesus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:12
verses.text: And (Carpocrates asserts) that the souls of these have originated from that supernal power, and that consequently they, as equally despising the world-making (angels), have been deemed worthy of the same power, and (of the privilege) to ascend to the same (place).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:13
verses.text: If, however, any one would despise earthly concerns more than did that (Saviour, Carpocrates says) that such a one would be able to become superior to (Jesus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:14
verses.text: The followers of this heretic) practise their magical arts and incantations, and spells and voluptuous feasts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:15
verses.text: And (they are in the habit of invoking the aid of) subordinate demons and dream-senders, and (of resorting to) the rest of the tricks (of sorcery), alleging that they possess power for now acquiring sway over the Archons and makers of this world, nay, even over all the works that are in it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:16
verses.text: (Now these heretics) have themselves been sent forth by Satan, for the purpose of slandering before the Gentiles the divine name of the Church.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:17
verses.text: (And the devil's object is,) that men hearing, now after one fashion and now after another, the doctrines of those (heretics), and thinking that all of us are people of the same stamp, may turn away their ears from the preaching of the truth, or that they also, looking, (without abjuring,) upon all the tenets of those (heretics), may speak hurtfully of us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:18
verses.text: (The followers of Carpocrates) allege that the souls are transferred from body to body, so far as that they may fill up (the measure of) all their sins.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:19
verses.text: When, however, not one (of these sins) is left, (the Carpocratians affirm that the soul) is then emancipated, and departs unto that God above of the world-making angels, and that in this way all souls will be saved.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:20
verses.text: If, however, some (souls), during the presence of the soul in the body for one life, may by anticipation become involved in the full measure of transgressions, they, (according to these heretics,) no longer undergo metempsychosis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:21
verses.text: (Souls of this sort,) however, on paying off at once all trespasses, will, (the Carpocratians say,) be emancipated from dwelling any more in a body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:22
verses.text: Certain, likewise, of these (heretics) brand their own disciples in the back parts of the lobe of the right ear.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 20:23
verses.text: And they make counterfeit images of Christ, alleging that these were in existence at the time (during which our Lord was on earth, and that they were fashioned) by Pilate.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 21

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 21:1
verses.text: The System of Cerinthus Concerning Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 21:2
verses.text: But a certain Cerinthus, himself being disciplined in the teaching of the Egyptians, asserted that the world was not made by the primal Deity, but by some virtue which was an offshoot from that Power which is above all things, and which (yet) is ignorant of the God that is above all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 21:3
verses.text: And he supposed that Jesus was not generated from a virgin, but that he was born son of Joseph and Mary, just in a manner similar with the rest of men, and that (Jesus) was more just and more wise (than all the human race).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 21:4
verses.text: And (Cerinthus alleges) that, after the baptism (of our Lord), Christ in form of a dove came down upon him, from that absolute sovereignty which is above all things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 21:5
verses.text: And then, (according to this heretic,) Jesus proceeded to preach the unknown Father, and in attestation (of his mission) to work miracles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 21:6
verses.text: It was, however, (the opinion of Cerinthus,) that ultimately Christ departed from Jesus, and that Jesus suffered and rose again; whereas that Christ, being spiritual, remained beyond the possibility of suffering.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 22

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 22:1
verses.text: Doctrine of the Ebionaeans.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 22:2
verses.text: The Ebionaeans, however, acknowledge that the world was made by Him Who is in reality God, but they propound legends concerning the Christ similarly with Cerinthus and Carpocrates.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 22:3
verses.text: They live conformably to the customs of the Jews, alleging that they are justified according to the law, and saying that Jesus was justified by fulfilling the law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 22:4
verses.text: And therefore it was, (according to the Ebionaeans,) that (the Saviour) was named (the) Christ of God and Jesus, since not one of the rest (of mankind) had observed completely the law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 22:5
verses.text: For if even any other had fulfilled the commandments (contained) in the law, he would have been that Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 22:6
verses.text: And the (Ebionaeans allege) that they themselves also, when in like manner they fulfil (the law), are able to become Christs; for they assert that our Lord Himself was a man in a like sense with all (the rest of the human family).

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 23

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 23:1
verses.text: The Heresy of Theodotus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 23:2
verses.text: But there was a certain Theodotus, a native of Byzantium, who introduced a novel heresy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 23:3
verses.text: He announces tenets concerning the originating cause of the universe, which are partly in keeping with the doctrines of the true Church, in so far as he acknowledges that all things were created by God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 23:4
verses.text: Forcibly appropriating, however, (his notions of) Christ from the school of the Gnostics, and of Cerinthus and Ebion, he alleges that (our Lord) appeared in some such manner as I shall now describe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 23:5
verses.text: (According to this, Theodotus maintains) that Jesus was a (mere) man, born of a virgin, according to the counsel of the Father, and that after he had lived promiscuously with all men, and had become pre-eminently religious, he subsequently at his baptism in Jordan received Christ, who came from above and descended (upon him) in form of a dove.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 23:6
verses.text: And this was the reason, (according to Theodotus,) why (miraculous) powers did not operate within him prior to the manifestation in him of that Spirit which descended, (and) which proclaims him to be the Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 23:7
verses.text: But (among the followers of Theodotus) some are disposed (to think) that never was this man made God, (even) at the descent of the Spirit; whereas others (maintain that he was made God) after the resurrection from the dead.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:1
verses.text: The Melchisedecians; The Nicolaitans.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:2
verses.text: While, however, different questions have arisen among them, a certain (heretic), who himself also was styled Theodotus, and who was by trade a banker, attempted to establish (the doctrine), that a certain Melchisedec constitutes the greatest power, and that this one is greater than Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:3
verses.text: And they allege that Christ happens to be according to the likeness (of this Melchisedec).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:4
verses.text: And they themselves, similarly with those who have been previously spoken of as adherents of Theodotus, assert that Jesus is a (mere) man, and that, in conformity with the same account (already given), Christ descended upon him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:5
verses.text: There are, however, among the Gnostics diversities of opinion; but we have decided that it would not be worth while to enumerate the silly doctrines of these (heretics), inasmuch as they are (too) numerous and devoid of reason, and full of blasphemy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:6
verses.text: Now, even those (of the heretics) who are of a more serious turn in regard of the Divinity, and have derived their systems of speculation from the Greeks, must stand convicted (of these charges).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:7
verses.text: But Nicolaus has been a cause of the wide-spread combination of these wicked men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:8
verses.text: He, as one of the seven (that were chosen) for the diaconate, was appointed by the Apostles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:9
verses.text: (But Nicolaus) departed from correct doctrine, and was in the habit of inculcating indifferency of both life and food.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 24:10
verses.text: And when the disciples (of Nicolaus) continued to offer insult to the Holy Spirit, John reproved them in the Apocalypse as fornicators and eaters of things offered unto idols.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 25

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 25:1
verses.text: The Heresy of Cerdon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 25:2
verses.text: But one Cerdon himself also, taking occasion in like manner from these (heretics) and Simon, affirms that the God preached by Moses and the prophets was not Father of Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 25:3
verses.text: For (he contends) that this (Father) had been known, whereas that the Father of Christ was unknown, and that the former was just, but the latter good.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 25:4
verses.text: And Marcion corroborated the tenet of this (heretic) in the work which he attempted to write, and which he styled Antitheses.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 25:5
verses.text: And he was in the habit, (in this book,) of uttering whatever slanders suggested themselves to his mind against the Creator of the universe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 25:6
verses.text: In a similar manner likewise (acted) Lucian, the disciple of this (heretic).

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:1
verses.text: The Doctrines of Apelles; Philumene, His Prophetess.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:2
verses.text: But Apelles, sprung from these, thus expresses himself, (saying) that there is a certain good Deity, as also Marcion supposed, and that he who created all things is just.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:3
verses.text: Now he, (according to Apelles,) was the Demiurge of generated entities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:4
verses.text: And (this heretic also maintains) that there is a third (Deity), the one who was in the habit of speaking to Moses, and that this (god) was of a fiery nature, and that there was another fourth god, a cause of evils.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:5
verses.text: But these he denominates angels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:6
verses.text: He utters, however, slanders against law and prophets, by alleging that the things that have been written are (of) human (origin), and are false.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:7
verses.text: And (Apelles) selects from the Gospels or (from the writings of) the Apostle (Paul) whatever pleases himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:8
verses.text: But he devotes himself to the discourses of a certain Philumene as to the revelations of a prophetess.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:9
verses.text: He affirms, however, that Christ descended from the power above; that is, from the good (Deity), and that he is the son of that good (Deity).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:10
verses.text: And (he asserts that Jesus) was not born of a virgin, and that when he did appear he was not devoid of flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:11
verses.text: (He maintains,) however, that (Christ) formed his body by taking portions of it from the substance of the universe: that is, hot and cold, and moist and dry.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:12
verses.text: And (he says that Christ), on receiving in this body cosmical powers, lived for the time he did in (this) world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:13
verses.text: But (he held that Jesus) was subsequently crucified by the Jews, and expired, and that, being raised up after three days, he appeared to his disciples.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:14
verses.text: And (the Saviour) showed them, (so Apelles taught,) the prints of the nails and (the wound) in his side, desirous of persuading them that he was in truth no phantom, but was present in the flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:15
verses.text: After, says (Apelles), he had shown them his flesh, (the Saviour) restored it to earth, from which substance it was (derived.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:16
verses.text: And this he did because) he coveted nothing that belonged to another.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:17
verses.text: (Though indeed Jesus) might use for the time being (what belonged to another), he yet in due course rendered to each (of the elements) what peculiarly belonged to them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:18
verses.text: And so it was, that after he had once more loosed the chains of his body, he gave back heat to what is hot, cold to what is cold, moisture to what is moist, (and) dryness to what is dry.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:19
verses.text: And in this condition (our Lord) departed to the good Father, leaving the seed of life in the world for those who through his disciples should believe in him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:20
verses.text: It appears to us that these (tenets) have been sufficiently explained.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VI 26:21
verses.text: Since, however, we have determined to leave unrefuted not one of those opinions that have been advanced by any (of the heretics), let us see what (system) also has been invented by the Docetae.
